item.title: The multifaceted impacts of the family planning policy: profound changes from social structure to economic politics
item.description:
China’s family planning policy, while limiting population growth, curbed familial development, disrupted traditional social structures, and suppressed the expansion of family businesses and political dynasties. Compared to South Korea’s chaebols and India’s family monopolies, its uniqueness is evident. Now that birth restrictions have been lifted, despite challenges like low birth rates, new monopoly risks must be guarded against, requiring a balance across various stakeholders.

The Rise and Fall of Population Control and Family-Style Development

The family planning policy, a fundamental national policy in China for nearly forty years, has yielded significant results. Data shows that between 1978 and 2007, the natural population growth rate decreased from 12‰ to 5.2‰, reducing births by over 400 million, and China’s share of the world population fell from 22.2% to 20.1%. This sharp decline in population growth has profoundly reshaped Chinese society’s family structure. For example, in family businesses, the number of children born to owners significantly decreased: birth rates of three or more children dropped from 40.63% before the policy to 18.46% afterward, while single-child births increased from 6.25% to 32.31%. This structural change has directly led to a substantial reduction in the pool of potential internal successors for family businesses, objectively inhibiting their ability to expand across generations.

Comparing South Korea and India, the differences are striking. Although South Korea has not implemented strict family planning policies, its birth rate has been persistently low (0.7 in 2023). However, chaebols maintain a firm grip on the national economy through cross-shareholdings and inheritance tax avoidance. The combined revenue of the five largest chaebols accounts for over 50% of South Korea’s GDP, with Samsung alone contributing 20%. India presents a different picture: family businesses contribute 79% of economic output, and six conglomerates control key sectors like telecommunications and steel. Twenty top companies account for 80% of the profits earned by all enterprises nationwide. The core difference lies in China’s family planning policy, which restricts family size and weakens the human resource base for family business expansion from the outset. Due to different policy environments, South Korea and India have allowed family influence to continuously permeate the economic sphere.

Restraining Monopolies and Social Structure Transformation

The impact of the family planning policy on the economic sphere is particularly evident in its suppression of monopolies. Reduced daughter numbers have prevented Chinese family businesses from forming chaebol-like groups, similar to those in South Korea. For example, Korean chaebols maintain control through “circular investment,” with families like Samsung holding only 2% of shares but controlling everything through a complex equity structure. In China, family businesses after the implementation of family planning often face the challenge of “succession,” leading them to introduce professional managers or implement diversified shareholding reforms. A study by The Paper found that the proportion of female successors in family businesses increased from 13.85% to 34.21% following family planning, with a significant increase in their educational attainment – the percentage with bachelor’s degrees or higher rising from 43.75% to 98.46%. While this transformation hasn’t completely eliminated family control, it has significantly reduced the possibility of monopolies dominated by single families.

At a societal level, the family planning policy accelerated the breakdown of the traditional family core model. Household size in China decreased from 4.41 people per household in 1982 to 2.62 in 2020, weakening the family’s functions in areas such as economics, education, and social support. In contrast, India maintains a household size of around 4 people, with the caste system deeply intertwined with familial power, resulting in limited social mobility. The shift towards smaller families in China has created space for individualistic development; by 2023, there were 240 million single adults, and the consumption market is seeing the rise of a “one-person economy,” further diluting the influence of family economics.

Decentralization of power in the political sphere

The family planning policy has had a profound impact on the political landscape as well. Traditionally, familial influence permeated local politics through kinship and marriage ties. For example, in Xinyi County, Henan Province, 161 political families virtually controlled all government departments, with 20% of cadres at the deputy section level or above being “second-generation officials.” However, the implementation of the family planning policy reduced household size, limiting the expansion of familial networks. Research from Peking University shows that the number of children among officials decreased after the policy was implemented, leading to a significant decline in the complexity of political family networks. Furthermore, the policy promoted education (increasing average years of schooling from 5.2 in 1982 to 10.9 in 2023), fostering social mobility and weakening the monopoly of familial influence on political resources.

Comparing South Korea and India, the deep entanglement of Korean chaebols with politics (such as financial transactions between Samsung executives and the government) and the hereditary family politics under India’s caste system highlight the uniqueness of Chinese policy. China’s birth planning policies have objectively reduced the possibility of power inheritance. While familial phenomena still exist in county-level politics, the overall trend is a dispersal of power structures. During the 2025 National People’s Congress, a CPPCC member proposed renaming the “Law on Population and Birth Planning” to the “Population and Fertility Law,” fully relaxing birth restrictions – a move that could further influence the evolution of future political ecology.

Challenges and Opportunities After Policy Adjustments

The implementation of the two-child policy in 2016 and the three-child policy in 2021 marked a significant shift in China’s birth policies. However, the effects have been limited: the birth rate in 2022 was only 1.18, far below the replacement level (2.1). Relaxing birth restrictions has a dual impact on family businesses: some entrepreneurs may strengthen their ability to pass down their legacy through having more children, as exemplified by Zong Fuli of Wahaha Group succeeding her father; conversely, high childcare costs (averaging 1 million yuan to raise a child to 18 in first-tier cities) and declining willingness among working women to have children are restricting family expansion.

Releasing restrictions on childbirth could spur new monopolies in the economic sphere. The three-child policy is driving consolidation within industries like maternal and infant care, with the early childhood education market projected to reach 162.13 billion yuan by 2025. Leading companies are integrating smaller firms through mergers and acquisitions, resulting in a CR5 concentration exceeding 55%. While this consolidation may increase efficiency, it also poses monopolistic risks. The government must balance encouraging childbirth with preventing excessive market concentration – for example, strengthening antitrust regulation while providing childcare subsidies (such as the 3000 yuan monthly milk powder subsidy for families with three children in Hangzhou) to alleviate household burdens.

Easing birth restrictions may subtly impact family influence in the political sphere. While restoring traditional networks of familial politics is difficult in the short term, a rise in larger families could create new grassroots political influence over time. Therefore, refining cadre selection mechanisms and strengthening oversight (such as establishing rules to prevent relatives from holding positions) remain key to preventing power inheritance.

International Lessons and Future Prospects

The experiences of South Korea and India demonstrate a close relationship between the rise and fall of family power and policy direction. South Korea achieved economic takeoff by supporting conglomerates (chaebols) but at the cost of social equity. India’s lack of effective policies to curb family monopolies has exacerbated wealth inequality. China’s birth planning policy, while controlling population growth, objectively suppressed the expansion of family influence, but also brought about issues like accelerated aging and labor shortages.

Looking ahead, China needs to seek a new balance between population policy and socioeconomic development. This involves increasing birth rates through supportive policies (such as extended maternity leave and universal childcare facilities), while strengthening antitrust enforcement to prevent family businesses from forming new monopolies through financial operations. In the political sphere, further progress is needed in grassroots democracy construction, improving oversight mechanisms, and ensuring transparent governance.

Overall, the family planning policy, as a significant driver of social change in China, has had an impact far beyond the population sphere. It reshaped family structures, economic models, and the political landscape, providing a path for China to avoid falling into a Korean-Indian style trap of familial monopolies. As policies adjust, balancing efficiency with fairness, freedom with order within this new demographic context will be a long-term challenge for China.

While the proportion of core subjects (language, math, English) remained stable, the overall volume contracted. Though the proportion of arts, music, and physical education increased, absolute numbers were limited (e.g., only 2 recruits in 2025 for each subject). Policy shifts towards “one-in, one-out” staffing restrictions, with teacher resources directed toward vocational education and remote areas, have led to a substantial reduction in traditional primary and secondary school positions; some subjects had zero planned hires in 2025.

item.title: The Celestial Realm of Medical Education and the Butterfly Effect of the Dong Xi-ying Incident
item.description:
The Peking Union Medical Center “4+4” program (4 years of non-medical undergraduate + 4 years of medical PhD), emphasizing interdisciplinary elite training, was exposed in 2025 due to the Dong Xiying incident. Her entry into the program allegedly leveraged family background (a lineage of medical professionals/researchers), raising questions about her educational qualifications and allegations of plagiarism. This highlights a conflict between the program’s elitist admissions practices and fairness, alongside unresolved issues regarding shortened training periods and supervised practice concerns.

Prompt

Writing a blog post: The origins and development of Concordia 4+4. Key points: A corner of Heaven, seen by mortals; Miss Dong’s family background; it’s impossible for a normal medical PhD to graduate in eight years; Miss Dong’s family and educational backgrounds.

The Disintegrated “Palace” of Medical Education: UnionMed 4+4

The “4+4” program at Peking Union Medical College, launched in 2018, has been regarded as a “heavenly palace” for medical education in China. Designed to emulate the American medical education system and guided by the principles of attracting individuals with diverse backgrounds, cultivating those with a passion for medicine, and recruiting talent from across the globe, it seeks to break new ground within the traditional medical education framework. Its core logic lies in 用4年非医学本科教育+4年医学博士培养，替代传统的5+3+3（本科5年+硕士3年+博士3年）模式, aiming to cultivate leading medical professionals with interdisciplinary expertise.

This pattern’s “Celestial Palace” attribute is reflected in three dimensions:

  1. Initially, applicants were required to have graduated from universities ranked within the top 50 by QS/Times/US News or among the top 10 US News liberal arts colleges (such as Barnard College). While later relaxed to include schools ranked in the top 100, a GPA of 3.6 or higher, or being in the top 30% of their class is still required.
  2. Utilizing an American organ-system integrated curriculum and PBL (Problem-Based Learning) teaching methods, students must complete core courses such as anatomy and pathology within four years, alongside clinical internships
  3. Although the passing rate for the licensing exam (95.2%) was slightly lower than the traditional eight-year program (98.5%), graduates largely enter Peking Union Medical Center affiliated hospitals, and their career development shows no significant difference from the traditional path

The Dong Xi-ying Incident: Cracks in “Heavenly Palace” Seen by a Mortal

In April 2025, a report of extramarital affairs involving Dr. Xiao Fei, a thoracic surgeon at the Sino-Japanese Friendship Hospital, unexpectedly exposed the “mystery” surrounding Peking Union Medical Center’s 4+4 project. The resume of the involved party, Dong Xiuying, raised three points of concern:

  1. 学历背景的模糊性:
  • Dong Xiyi claims to have graduated from Columbia University, but in fact attended its affiliated Barnard College (ranked 14th by US News for liberal arts colleges in 2025). Although Barnard meets the “top 20 liberal arts college” requirement, its diploma simultaneously lists “Barnard College” and “Columbia University,” which can easily be mistaken for Columbia’s main campus in the domestic recruitment market.
  • The path of a bachelor’s degree in economics followed by a doctorate in clinical medicine, while meeting the “multidisciplinary background” requirement of the 4+4 program, has been questioned for lacking a foundation in pre-medical coursework. Furthermore, his doctoral dissertation, “Research on Multi-Modal Image Fusion Technology in Medical Image Analysis,” has been accused of significant similarity to a Beijing University of Science and Technology invention patent, raising concerns of academic misconduct.
  1. 家庭背景的特殊性:
  • His father is a secretary at China Metallurgical Research Institute, his mother is an associate dean at the Beihang University Engineering Technology Research Institute, his grandfather is an academician in the field of imaging at Peking Union Medical College, his maternal grandparents are foreign academicians in materials science, and his aunts and uncles are professors at Beihang University. This “medicine + research + university” family background provides him with hidden resources such as letters of recommendation (requiring two biomedical associate professors) and research collaborations (such as patents from Beihang University).
  • During residency, he switched from thoracic surgery to urology, with research spanning multiple fields including orthopedics, gastroenterology, and imaging, leading to accusations of “paving the way with resources.”
  1. 学制争议的放大:
  • Traditional medicine doctoral programs require 11 years (5+3+3), while the 4+4 program compresses this to 8 years. Despite Peking Union Medical College’s emphasis on “integrated curriculum” and “early clinical exposure,” some doctors note that its clinical internship time (12 months) is less than the traditional eight-year system (18 months), potentially impacting skill development.
  • Some training bases allow a one-year reduction in required training for 4+4 graduates, raising concerns about fairness within the industry

The Dilemma of Medical Education Behind the Controversy

The Dong Xi-ying case reflects the deep-rooted contradictions in China’s medical education system

  1. 精英化与公平性的冲突:
  • The “application-review system” of the 4+4 program is essentially a transplant of the American medical school model, but China lacks standardized exams like the MCAT, and subjective evaluations such as letters of recommendation and research experience are easily influenced by family background
  • Data shows that among the 2023 graduates (4+4 program), 30% came from Tsinghua, Peking University, and Fudan University, 25% from overseas prestigious universities, indicating a significant influence of family background on applications
  1. 学制改革的现实困境:
  • Research output (e.g., publications) from 4+4 medical students is significantly lower than that of traditional eight-year programs, leading to criticism of prioritizing clinical experience over research
  • Top-tier hospitals prioritize the Peking Union Medical Center brand, while community hospitals are cautious about the clinical abilities of 4+4 program graduates
  1. 医学教育的国际接轨之惑:
  • The US 4+4 model requires passing the MCAT and completing 3-7 years of residency, while China’s 4+4 program simplifies admission and residency, resulting in a superficial resemblance
  • According to data from the Ministry of Education, in 2024 nationwide medical doctoral program admissions, programs following the 4+4 model accounted for less than 5%, and their widespread promotion still faces challenges

Reconstructing the “Celestial Palace” Order of Medical Education

The controversy surrounding the Union 4+4 project is fundamentally a clash between elite education and public expectations. When a corner of “heavenly palace” (referring to top-tier medical training) is glimpsed by ordinary people, it exposes not only flaws in individual cases but also deep-seated contradictions within the entire medical education system. Future reforms need to focus on three levels:

  1. Introduce standardized exams (like China’s version of the MCAT) to reduce the influence of subjective factors such as letters of recommendation
  2. Restore the internship period for 4+4 graduates to 3 years to ensure clinical competency standards are met
  3. Establish an academic integrity review mechanism, with rigorous originality verification for interdisciplinary research

Medical education should not be a privilege for a few, but a true incubator for medical excellence. Only when fairness in selection, rigor in training, and standardization of career development are comprehensively ensured can this “medical education experiment” truly take root.

Add to position on a pullback (on the left side)

A “left-side topping up” strategy is an investment approach where investors buy in batches during a sustained stock price decline, anticipating the price is nearing a bottom to reduce holding costs and profit from future price increases

This method falls under the category of “left-side trading,” meaning taking a counter-trend position before the market has clearly bottomed out. In practice, investors typically employ a “pyramid” accumulation strategy, gradually increasing buy quantities as the price declines to lower their average holding cost. For example, initially buying a certain number of shares; if the price continues to fall, they increase their buying volume at a lower price, and so on.

Relatively speaking, “right-side trading” involves buying after a clear market trend and price recovery signal, offering lower risk but potentially missing early gains. Therefore, investors should choose a strategy that aligns with their risk tolerance, financial situation, and market judgment.

Valuation theory

Valuation theory is a core concept in finance, aiming to assess the intrinsic value of assets or companies and provide a basis for investment decisions. Through valuation, investors can determine whether the current market price of an asset is reasonable and formulate corresponding investment strategies.

  1. This method is based on the expected future cash flows of an asset, which are then discounted to their present value using an appropriate discount rate. The DCF method emphasizes intrinsic value and is suitable for evaluating companies with stable and predictable earnings.

  2. This method assesses a company’s relative value by comparing its valuation metrics (e.g., P/E, P/B, P/S) to those of comparable companies in the same industry. Relative valuation is easy to implement and widely used for quick assessments and peer comparisons.

  3. This method determines a company’s value by assessing its net asset value, which is the difference between total assets and liabilities. The asset-based approach is suitable for asset-dominant companies such as real estate firms or capital-intensive businesses.

item.title: A dramatic market shift before and after National Day: soaring highs followed by plunging lows
item.description:
Ahead of China’s National Day holiday in 2024, the stock market saw a remarkable surge, followed by a dramatic plunge after the break. This “rollercoaster” experience for investors has prompted deep reflection on policy, economics, and market dynamics.

Here’s the English translation: “Written as a news report, this blog post focuses on the stock market surge preceding last year’s National Day holiday, followed by the subsequent sharp decline after the holiday.”

Stock market surge before National Day: A policy-driven frenzy

For the five trading days leading up to China’s National Day in 2024, the Chinese stock market surged from a slump into a “boiling” state. On September 30th, A-share markets saw broad gains with significant volume; major indices all reached historic highs. The Shanghai Index rose 8.06%, the Shenzhen Component Index climbed 10.67%, and the Growth Enterprise Market Index soared 15.36%. The B share index set a record for the largest single-day increase, jumping 22.84%. Market sentiment was extremely bullish, with daily turnover on Shanghai, Shenzhen, and Beijing exchanges reaching 2.61 trillion yuan – a substantial increase of 1.1559 trillion yuan from the previous trading day. Over 5300 stocks across all markets rose collectively, creating a “sea of red” scenario.

The driving force behind this recent market rally stems from the concentrated release of a series of unexpected government policies and the resulting shifts in market expectations. On September 24th, the People’s Bank of China announced measures including cutting the reserve requirement ratio, lowering interest rates, reducing mortgage rates on existing loans, and unifying minimum down payment ratios for mortgages. The Central Political Bureau meeting on September 26th emphasized increasing counter-cyclical adjustments through fiscal and monetary policies to boost capital markets and encourage long-term funds to enter the market. On September 30th, a cluster of four real estate support policies were introduced. These measures demonstrate the government’s determination to stabilize the market and economic growth.

Post-National Day Stock Market Plunge: Calmness and Adjustment After the Celebration

However, market sentiment plummeted after the National Day holiday. On October 8th, A-shares opened strongly with near limit-up gains, but following this sharp opening, the market experienced significant volatility, ultimately closing higher than it opened but lower than it closed. Since then, the market’s focus has continued to decline; as of October 16th, the Shanghai Composite Index saw a swing of over 15% and a cumulative drop of more than 470 points. From October 8th to 10th, core A-share indices across the board declined, with the Growth Enterprise Market Index falling by 6.21%. This recent sharp decline is due to a combination of factors: digesting risks accumulated from previous rapid gains, and adjustments in market expectations regarding policy. Some investors believe the short-term effects of policies are already apparent, while long-term results remain to be seen. Volatility in overseas markets has also impacted A-shares. On October 9th, the Hang Seng Index plummeted 9.41% and the A50 futures contract fell 10.4%, further intensifying the market’s downturn.

Reflection on and Prospects for the Market

The sharp market fluctuations before and after National Day have prompted deep reflection on policy, the economy, and market dynamics. While policy stimulus has shown a significant short-term effect, its long-term impact remains to be seen. The rapid market rises and falls also serve as a reminder for investors to remain rational and avoid emotional investing.

Whether A-share market can achieve a genuine “long-term bull” trend still depends on whether policies effectively reach the real economy and ultimately drive substantial improvements in economic fundamentals. Investors should closely monitor policy implementation and changes in economic data, adjusting their investment strategies accordingly.

The stock market’s surge and subsequent crash around National Day were a contest between policy and the market, as well as a test of investor psychology. This “extreme” volatility revealed both the power of the market and the influence of policy. We will see how the market unfolds next.

item.title: Nezha breaks out during Spring Festival season
item.description:
For Chinese people, watching movies has become an essential entertainment during the Spring Festival season when families reunite. This year’s Spring Festival film releases were dominated by “Ne Zha,” which was incredibly popular and sparked widespread discussion. The buzz surrounding it is reminiscent of “Wolf Warrior,” both films carrying a strong patriotic theme that evokes a sense of national pride.

The unexpected success of “Nezha” during the Spring Festival season, sparking a sense of national pride reminiscent of films like “Wolf Warrior,” demonstrates a patriotic theme. While acknowledging significant progress, the film isn’t quite as impressive as some claim. As a gamer, I find many aspects feel overly slick and the fight scenes lean heavily towards an MMO style. Numerous reports indicate people buying tickets to see it but ultimately not going due to its performance pressure.

The fight scenes lack texture

As a gamer, I usually spend my days immersed in online games and didn’t have high expectations for movies. But the buzz around “Ne Zha” was undeniable; everyone was talking about it, so I figured I’d check it out. Once I entered the theater and saw the visuals, I felt a jolt. While the production quality has improved considerably, some scenes looked a bit greasy. And the fight sequences? They were too heavily influenced by online game aesthetics. Having played games for so long, this visual style is too similar to certain in-game environments, lacking the texture one expects from a film.

Crazy movie fans

After seeing the movie, I checked online and saw that quite a few people bought tickets for “The Devil’s Child” but didn’t actually watch it, all to boost its box office. That’s impressive dedication – clearly, there’s a lot of enthusiasm for this film, and everyone wants to do something to support it.

Plot

Let’s recall “Wolf Warrior” when Wu Jing shouted, “Whoever dares offend China will be punished no matter how far away they are,” many people were thrilled and felt that our Chinese military was so powerful, and our country so strong. While “Ne Zha” doesn’t have such direct patriotic slogans, it vividly showcases traditional Chinese culture. We grew up listening to the stories of mythological figures like Nezha and Ao Bing; the film portrays their conflicts, love, and growth with depth and emotion – isn’t that the charm of Chinese culture?

Let’s talk about Nezha. Misunderstood and looked down upon since childhood, yet he refused to give in, declaring “My fate is my own, not the heavens’.” That spirit is so much like the resilience ingrained in us Chinese people. No matter how great the difficulty, we don’t back down, but strive to change our destiny through effort. Ao Bing also exemplifies this – burdened by a family mission, seemingly cold but truly kind-hearted, willing to sacrifice himself for his friends. We often see such friendship and responsibility in real life, don’t we?

Advancement of animated films

Although “The Devils Who Laugh” isn’t perfect, it effectively combines traditional Chinese culture with modern film technology, showcasing the progress of Chinese animation. Just as “Wolf Warrior” demonstrated a breakthrough for Chinese cinema in action films, this kind of advancement gives us hope that Chinese movies can shine on the international stage and allow foreigners to appreciate the brilliance of Chinese culture.

As Chinese people, wherever we go, we carry our nation and culture in our hearts. Films like “Ne Zha” and “Wolf Warrior” are like keys, unlocking a sense of national pride deep within us. They allow us to experience the strength of our country and the charm of our culture amidst laughter and joy, inspiring us to work hard in our respective fields and contribute to the prosperity and development of our nation. This is likely why these films have become so popular and resonate with such strong feelings of national pride. We hope for more films like this in the future, to keep this sense of pride brimming.

item.title: Making money takes time; rushing it wont help
item.description:
Reflecting on years of stock trading, while I haven’t made a fortune, I also haven’t lost too much. The biggest issue is an unreasonable cash flow plan and unstable mindset. Currently, my primary income comes from work – a fixed salary. My tolerance for financial fluctuations remains at the level of bonds and bank deposits. However, people are inherently greedy; buying too little means you won’t profit when prices rise, while buying too much leads to losses when they fall. A stable mindset is therefore crucial; it helps steady our ship of wealth.

Investing through stock trading: The importance of mindset

Historical Loss Cases

Besides dabbling in small-cap and newly listed stocks when I first started, the investments I’ve focused on since have been primarily blue-chip large-cap stocks: Industrial Bank, China Unicom, Hengan Electronics, ZTE, and various large-cap index funds

Ultimately, it stemmed from greed wanting more—rushing to increase holdings at the start, then facing a cash flow crisis. Expenses like insurance, buying property, and getting married were major drains on funds; the overall plan lacked sufficient financial buffer, leading to later shortages.

Buy blue-chip stocks, it’s like relying on [someone] dependable

  • When Evergrande ran into problems, bank stocks plummeted, allowing for a successful opportunity to sell off. However, this demonstrates a flawed understanding of the broader economy – real estate’s share in the national economy is too significant, with far-reaching implications that cannot be ignored. The subsequent market decline and the sustained rise of dividend stocks over roughly two years reflect this.
  • The early stages of the trade war saw significant damage, with stock prices falling sharply, but they gradually recovered afterward
  • This stock belongs to the former employer. After Ant Financial’s divestiture, the price dropped significantly, but it has market makers who can push it up several times a year. With proper position sizing, losses will be minimal.

Greed: The “monster” that devours reason

When stock prices rise steadily and investors’ paper profits increase, greed quietly takes root. Many, seeing prices already at high levels, still fantasize about continued upward trends and seek greater returns, unwilling to take profits. Blinded by greed, they forget market rules and the existence of risk. For example, during speculative surges in certain hot-topic stocks, some investors, witnessing short-term doubling or even multiple times increases, become deeply involved, continuously adding positions with the hope of being the last winners. However, markets don’t stay exuberant forever; when bubbles burst and prices plummet, these greed-driven investors often suffer heavy losses. Greed robs them of their ability to analyze and decide rationally, turning them into “gamblers” rather than wise investors.

Fear: Shackles binding your hands and feet

Fear is the opposite of greed. Fear is equally destructive in the stock market. When market conditions turn sharply downward and prices plummet, investors easily panic. This fear erodes their confidence; even with fundamentally sound stocks, they rush to sell to avoid further losses. For example, during the global financial crisis, many high-quality blue-chip stocks also fell dramatically. Some investors, overwhelmed by fear, failed to recognize the long-term value of these companies and sold their shares at rock-bottom prices, missing out on substantial returns from subsequent market rebounds and company performance growth. Fear not only causes short-term losses but can also create a lasting psychological shadow, deterring them from re-entering the market and causing them to miss investment opportunities.

Blindly following trends: A “fog” that obscures direction

Blindly following the crowd is another common psychological trap for investors in stock trading and wealth management. In an era of information overload, investment advice, market rumors, and trending news abound. Many investors lack independent thinking and judgment skills, blindly imitating others’ actions. Seeing others profit from buying a particular stock, they rush to buy without careful consideration; hearing so-called “insider tips,” they invest everything they have. This blind following neglects the necessary research and analysis of individual stocks, leaving investors lost like ships in fog, losing their direction. For example, some concept stocks may generate short-term gains for followers initially, but as hype fades, prices plummet, turning those unaware and blindly following into “bag holders.” They fail to realize that each investor has different risk tolerance, investment goals, and time horizons; what works for others might not work for them.

Overconfidence: A Hidden “Shoal”

Overconfidence is a significant issue in the mindset of stock and financial investments. After experiencing initial investment successes, some investors become inflated with pride, believing they have mastered market patterns and can accurately predict price movements. They disregard the complexity and uncertainty of the market, leading to excessive trading, blindly expanding their investment scale, and even using high leverage for speculation. However, the market is unpredictable, and overconfident investors often suffer significant losses from unexpected market fluctuations. For example, inexperienced but initially successful investors may believe they possess professional investment skills and begin frequent buying and selling while continuously increasing their investments. When systemic risks or negative news about individual stocks emerge, they fail to stop their losses in time due to their overconfidence, resulting in substantial capital erosion. Overconfidence is like a submerged reef, appearing calm and harmless on the surface but capable of wrecking an investor’s financial ship unexpectedly.

How to adjust your mindset for sound financial management

  • Establish a correct investment philosophy: Investors should understand that stock trading and wealth management are for the long-term, stable growth of assets, not for getting rich quick. Through learning investment knowledge, understanding market patterns, and adopting value investing and long-term investment principles, avoid being swayed by short-term gains and market sentiment. For example, thoroughly research a company’s fundamentals – its profitability, industry position, management team, etc. – to select stocks with long-term investment value, rather than blindly chasing short-term trends.
  • Develop a sound investment plan: Based on your financial situation, risk tolerance, and investment goals, create a scientific and reasonable plan. Clearly define key elements such as investment amount, timeframe, expected return, and stop-loss point, and adhere to the plan strictly. This helps avoid impulsive decisions driven by emotional fluctuations. For example, limit each stock’s allocation to a certain percentage of your total assets; take profits when prices reach your target gains, and cut losses decisively when they hit your stop-loss level.
  • Control your emotions and stay calm: When facing market volatility, learn to manage your emotions and remain calm and rational. Relieve investment pressure through methods like distraction, exercise, and communication. Avoid letting emotions negatively impact your investment decisions. When the market experiences significant fluctuations, first calmly analyze the reasons, combine your investment strategy with the fundamentals of the stocks, and make a rational judgment instead of blindly following trends or panicking.
  • Continuous learning and reflection are essential in the ever-evolving stock market. Investors must consistently acquire new knowledge and skills, stay informed about macroeconomic trends, industry developments, and company information to improve their investment capabilities. Regularly reflecting on investment behavior, summarizing lessons learned, identifying issues with mindset and decision-making, and making timely adjustments are also crucial. For example, after each investment, review the entire process, analyze successes and failures, and consider how to avoid similar errors in future investments.

Investing in the stock market is a long and challenging journey where mindset plays a crucial role. Maintaining rationality, composure, humility, and independent thinking are essential for navigating market volatility and achieving wealth preservation and growth. Investors should consider cultivating a positive mindset as a fundamental part of their investment process, enabling them to steer their financial future successfully.

item.title: The Mystery of Spring Festival Movie Ticket Prices: Differences Between Online and Offline Sales
item.description:
During the Spring Festival, a family of seven or eight wanted to see a movie. We planned to buy tickets on Taopihao and Maoyan, but saw the price was 60 yuan. Luckily, we had a cinema recharge card that required purchasing tickets at the front desk in person. Thinking to ask about any discounts, we were surprised to find the same showing only cost 35 yuan there – quite a difference!

Hidden platform fees

While online ticketing platforms offer convenience, their service fees are significant. They invest in user-friendly features like seat selection and purchase history tracking, which require funding. These costs are passed on to the customer through service fees, resulting in higher ticket prices.

Cinema Differentiation Strategies

Demand for movie tickets during the Spring Festival is surging, and theaters are using tiered pricing to maximize profits. Online platforms have high traffic, so many people buy tickets in advance online, resulting in higher prices for those tickets. Meanwhile, walk-in customers buying at the front desk receive lower prices to attract them.

The pricing logic behind profit sharing

Online platforms and cinemas cooperate through revenue-sharing models that affect ticket prices. To ensure profitability, platforms take a percentage of the box office, leading to higher ticket costs. Cinema counters, without intermediary fees, offer more affordable tickets due to lower costs.

Tips for Buying Tickets

Don’t just look at online platforms when buying tickets. Try calling the cinema directly or visiting the front desk – you might find a surprise. If you’re a frequent moviegoer, consider getting a membership card to enjoy member discounts and save money.

item.title: An Analysis of Political Elements in 2025 Spring Festival Films
item.description:
It’s been a while since I went out during Spring Festival season, but this time I saw two movies and had a different feeling

This article explores the new trends in the 2025 Spring Festival film season, focusing on “Detective Chinatown 1900” and “New Deity: The Magchild Incites the Sea.” The former uses the backdrop of San Francisco’s Chinatown in 1900 to depict the discrimination and oppression faced by Chinese people, reflecting the social and political environment. The latter, as an animated film, employs rich metaphorical elements to satirize the current international political landscape—for example, Jade Pure Palace resembling the Pentagon alluding to the American political system, dollar signs on the Tianyuan Cauldron symbolizing US dollar hegemony, the Immortal Jade Tablet mirroring the green card suggesting hierarchical status, and the Soul-Destroying Pill akin to biological weapons hinting at malicious actions. Both films offer a new viewing experience and prompt reflection on the relationship between cinematic art and political expression.

Innovation in Spring Festival film styles

Traditionally, Spring Festival films have been lighthearted and family-friendly, aiming to help audiences relax during the holiday season and rarely addressing sensitive political topics. However, this year’s 2025 Spring Festival lineup breaks with convention; “Detective Chinatown 1900” and “New God of War: Nezha Revolution” incorporate rich political elements, sparking widespread discussion among viewers and ushering in a new era for Spring Festival films.

A Vivid Reflection of the Era’s Politics

“The Lost Tiger” is set in 1900 San Francisco’s Chinatown, a time when Chinese immigrants faced severe racial discrimination and oppression. As the protagonists investigate a case, they must navigate not only the mystery but also societal prejudice and unfair treatment. The film’s portrayal of racism and power struggles realistically reflects the social and political climate of the era, revealing the arduous struggle for survival and dignity undertaken by Chinese immigrants during that turbulent time—a situation with underlying political issues worthy of deeper consideration.

This historical context inevitably brings to mind the current challenges faced by overseas Chinese in the business world, such as the TikTok and Zhou Shuzhong incident

On December 6, 2024, local time, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit rejected TikTok’s request, upholding the constitutionality of a law requiring its sale on national security grounds. TikTok CEO Shou Zi Chew wrote in a memo to employees that the next step will be “seeking an injunction and awaiting review by the U.S. Supreme Court.” The event stems from the “Protecting Americans from Foreign Adversary Controlled Applications” law, which mandates that ByteDance divest its U.S. TikTok operations within 270 days of the bill’s passage, with a final sale deadline of January 19, 2025.

Previously, Shou Zi Chew faced numerous challenges at various hearings. On January 31, 2024, during a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing on “Big Tech and the Online Child Sexual Exploitation Crisis,” prominent anti-China lawmaker Tom Cotton repeatedly questioned him with 8 nationality-related inquiries, including his own citizenship, whether he had applied for Chinese or American citizenship, and even the nationalities of his wife and children. Despite the hearing’s focus being on online child sexual exploitation, the senator shifted the topic to TikTok’s ownership by the Chinese company ByteDance, forcing Chew to answer questions unrelated to the theme. Similar to the unwarranted discrimination faced by Chinese in “Detective Chinatown 1900,” Shou Zi Chew is experiencing unfair treatment and scrutiny in the business world due to TikTok’s background. These events reflect that overseas Chinese have consistently encountered significant external obstacles when pursuing their own development and protecting their rights across different eras. Whether it was racial discrimination a century ago or today’s political maneuvering in commerce, these situations warrant deep reflection.

An Analysis of the Political Metaphors Behind “Ne Zha: The Demon Child”

While appearing as an ordinary animated film, “Ne Zha: The Demon Child” is rich with political allegories in its settings and plot

  • The Jade Void Palace is portrayed as the supreme power center of the realm, with an architectural style similar to the Pentagon, predominantly white in color, symbolizing Western powers using “universal values” as a pretext for hegemony. The “Demon Eradication Team,” led by the Limitless Immortal Elder, and its subordinates, Lù Nán and Hè Nǚ, are seen as corresponding to the US alliance system involving Japan and South Korea. The Jade Void Palace’s “online meeting” scene, with the Twelve Golden Immortals discussing the “War of the Conferred Gods,” mirrors a NATO summit led by the United States, ostensibly maintaining order while suppressing other nations.
  • The Tianyuan Cauldron, used for alchemy in Yuxu Palace, features dollar signs at its entrance, symbolizing how the United States “alchemizes” resources from other nations through economic hegemony. In the film, Wuliang Xianweng throws the dragon clan into the cauldron under the guise of “acting on behalf of heaven,” mirroring certain countries exploiting others by leveraging “international rules.”
  • Nezha’s immortal identity jade pendant, with its color and design resembling the U.S. green card, symbolizes the celestial realm’s exclusion and stratification of “outsiders,” hinting at the identity differences and unequal treatment between different countries and groups in reality.
  • The forced consumption of the Soul-Destroying Pill by Nezha, compelled by the Immortal Wonderman, resembles a bioweapon and satirizes certain nations that, under the guise of “saving the world,” engage in destruction and devastation abroad
  • The Seven-Colored Treasure Lotus, crucial for reshaping the bodies of Nezha and Ao Bing, symbolizes energy and technology lifelines monopolized by powerful nations. Obtaining its “essence” requires passing the Yu Xu Palace’s “immortality exam,” reflecting developing countries’ dependence on core resources and exploitation within a hegemonic system. The lotus’s temporary failure and recovery conditions allude to small nations’ survival challenges amidst energy crises.

A Deep Reflection on Film Art and Political Expression

These films, integrated with political elements during the nationwide Chinese New Year moviegoing boom, offer audiences a new viewing experience—no longer just entertainment, but more like a mirror reflecting political issues within history and reality. This prompts deeper reflection on the relationship between cinematic art and political expression. Will directors increasingly convey their views on society and politics through film? Can cinema, as a powerful cultural medium, balance artistic expression with greater attention to and contemplation of social realities? These questions warrant thorough exploration while enjoying films, and we look forward to more exciting developments from the film industry in fusing art and reality.

item.title: The two major U.S. political parties—the Democratic Party and the Republican Party.
item.description:
The Democratic and Republican parties have significant differences in political ideology, policy proposals, and social values

Political Ideology and Policy Proposals

  • The Democratic Party leans liberal, advocating for government involvement in economic and social matters. It supports social welfare programs, environmental protection, and multiculturalism. On taxation, the party favors tax cuts for low-to-middle income groups while raising rates on high earners and corporations. Regarding social issues, it supports abortion rights, same-sex marriage, and strict gun control. In foreign policy, the Democratic Party emphasizes multilateralism and diplomacy, preferring to resolve global issues through international cooperation.

  • The party leans conservative, advocating for limited government intervention and emphasizing individual freedom and a market economy. On tax policy, they support across-the-board tax cuts, believing they should benefit all income levels. Regarding social issues, they oppose abortion and same-sex marriage and support the right to bear arms. In foreign policy, they tend towards a hawkish stance, supporting the use of military force to protect national interests.

The significance of Trump’s rise to power

Donald Trump’s re-election as U.S. President in 2024 signifies the Republican Party’s dominance in American politics. Trump’s policy positions include:

  • Trump advocates for economic growth through tax cuts and deregulation, particularly supporting the development of traditional manufacturing and energy industries. He also favors protectionist trade policies, renegotiating or withdrawing from existing trade agreements to protect American economic interests.

  • Trump plans to strengthen border security, restrict illegal immigration, and impose stricter screening and limitations on legal immigrants. He also supports limiting refugee and asylum claims to protect national security.

  • Trump favors unilateralism, emphasizes “America First,” reduces reliance on international organizations, reassesses relations with allies, and employs tougher diplomacy when necessary. He also plans to expand fossil fuel production and usage while easing environmental restrictions.

A second Trump term could lead to significant shifts in US domestic policy and have far-reaching impacts on global politics and economics. His policies are likely to draw international attention and responses, particularly regarding trade, environment, and human rights.

item.title: From Games to Family: Why We Gradually Drift Away from Virtual Worlds as We Grow Up
item.description:
What were the happiest times playing games – sneaking to play Tank Battle, Super Mario, and Contra on our family’s TV as a child, or secretly playing Age of Empires on our family’s computer with my cousin, or later in college, playing Devil May Cry and League of Legends with my roommates?

Childhood had no worries, and when you played, you were completely absorbed in it – a level of immersion that’s impossible to find again as an adult

As times change and society progresses, we who were once active in virtual worlds are gradually realizing that the game platform filled with joy and competition seems to be drifting away from our lives. The disconnection of game social links, accompanied by players’ gradual departure, is not only due to technological advancements and the replacement of games themselves, but also because of a shift in our life’s focus. As we grow older, we become busy with marriage and having children, and the main thread of life gradually shifts from personal entertainment to family responsibilities. Today, let’s discuss the underlying reasons behind this trend.

The Disappearance of Gaming Socialization: A Tug-of-War Between Virtual and Real Worlds

For many, games weren’t just entertainment during their youth; they were a social outlet. Popular online multiplayer games offered challenges and competition while connecting players worldwide, creating virtual communities. Playing dungeons and team battles with friends was part of life back then, as were late-night voice chats and sharing daily experiences – memories we cherish.

However, with time, more and more players have found that this virtual social experience lacks lasting appeal. As games are updated and new platforms emerge, players increasingly find more interactive ways to socialize outside of gaming. In-game friendships gradually fade from view, and many previously active social connections within the game eventually dissolve.

Games and Responsibility: A Shift in Life’s Focus After Adulthood

Entering adulthood, responsibilities gradually increase. Many young people once invested significant time in games, but with the start of their careers or shared living/family formation, these previously essential leisure activities are squeezed by life’s obligations. Marriage, having children, and even caring for parents – these major responsibilities require choices regarding energy and time.

Gaming has become a thing of the past, replaced by the prioritization of family life. Many young people who once “struggled” in games are gradually realizing that real-life is the most important matter. Especially after having children, the focus of their lives shifts completely to family, and gaming is pushed to the periphery.

From Games to Family: How Changes in Life Affect Our Entertainment Choices

In our life experiences, family is one of the most important components. Once entering family life, time and energy become more specific and limited. To care for children and spend time with their partners, many young parents find they no longer have enough time to focus on games they once loved. Sometimes, they even lose interest in game updates and new releases. Gradually, social media platforms and offline interactions with friends and family become the preferred way for many people to socialize.

This doesn’t mean we’ve completely abandoned entertainment, but rather chosen ways more suitable for our current life stage. Many friends who used to connect through games may now maintain contact via other means—family gatherings, meals together, or short trips—due to diverging life paths.

Farewell to the virtual world: How do we view this shift?

For many who once immersed themselves in gaming, saying goodbye to game-related social connections isn’t easy. That virtual world, which brought us joy and a sense of accomplishment, has become part of our memories. However, farewell doesn’t mean severing ties completely; it means making different choices as life changes, balancing our roles in the real world. As we mature from youthful boys to responsible adults, while games still hold value, they can no longer be the main theme of our lives.

In reality, this shift reflects a facet of human adaptability—our ability to adjust our focus and lifestyle according to different stages. When responsibilities and family become central to life, gaming socialization is no longer a priority but rather an occasional pastime.

Future games: may usher in another wave of “sense of belonging.”

Of course, with social development and technological advancements, the forms and content of games are constantly evolving. For example, modern online multiplayer games are increasingly moving towards more relaxed and flexible approaches, and some even prioritize family interaction and parent-child relationships. In the future, we may see more game formats that better integrate into family life and provide players with healthier, more balanced social experiences.

Just as many people still feel nostalgia and passion when talking about “childhood games,” perhaps we, in the future, will also unexpectedly revisit those past games, bringing new understanding and experience, and re-enter that virtual world

Life is changing, but love remains

Whether it’s games or family, life’s changes consistently accompany our growth. We gradually realize that while virtual worlds offer endless joy and excitement, we ultimately return to reality, to the warmest place – home. There’s no need to regret leaving games, as each stage of life has its own unique meaning. These changes are what make us more complete.

item.title: The Art of Balancing Bank Marketing Strategies with Personal Financial Management
item.description:
Recently, home renovations have significantly increased our daily expenses. We typically use credit cards and pay them off within the billing cycle. Although we have sufficient cash on hand, we prefer to keep it in money market funds for extra interest income. At the same time, to ensure financial stability, we’ve set up automatic payments to promptly repay credit card bills upon due date.

Bank status: Deposits increasing, loans decreasing

Amidst growing economic uncertainty, people are more inclined to save rather than consume or invest. This leads to increased bank deposits but also requires banks to pay higher interest rates. Conversely, reduced consumption and investment activity lowers loan demand, making it difficult for banks to generate income through lending.

To attract and retain customers, banks are compelled to offer more competitive deposit rates, further compressing their net interest margins. Simultaneously, to stimulate economic growth and consumption, the central bank may implement policies to lower benchmark interest rates, which will also affect loan rates and subsequently impact bank profitability.

Bank marketing strategies: Cultivating user habits

Repayment is approaching soon. First, Bank of Communications offered me a one-year interest-free installment plan. Shortly after, China Merchants Bank provided a 2.5% discount on installment interest, resulting in an annual rate of just 1.9%. Faced with these offers, I chose to accept the installment services from both banks.

Banks are truly investing heavily to cultivate user habits. According to the definition of a bank’s revenue stream, I should be considered a valuable client. Given the current difficulty in lending, banks are essentially preparing for potential future financial difficulties on my part by fostering my installment mindset—allowing them to earn more interest income when that time comes. After all, credit card interest rates are well-known to be high.

…and laid the groundwork for future profits

The importance of personal financial management

While bank installment offers may seem appealing, users should recognize the risks of over-relying on credit card installments. We should carefully consider our repayment ability and future financial needs to avoid falling into long-term debt for short-term convenience. Key to personal finance management is balancing current needs with future planning.

In today’s digital age, gaming has evolved beyond a simple form of entertainment and become an integral part of daily life. From a psychological perspective, games play different roles in the mental development of people across various age groups and are closely linked to social interaction and recreation.

Mental state

Young people are in a stage of exploring themselves and establishing their identity, therefore games can allow them to try on different roles and lives, satisfying curiosity and the desire for exploration. As they age, personal interests and values gradually stabilize, and games may no longer align with their life goals and interests.

Social attributes

At the same time, gaming has become a social activity, especially for young people. They make friends and build social networks through games, which serve as a bridge for socializing. However, as people age, their social circles stabilize and social needs may be met through more mature means, diminishing the role of gaming in socialization.

Taking a girl out

In China, due to a lack of relationship education, children are pressured to focus solely on academics by their parents, then immediately pushed into relationships upon graduation—a very common phenomenon

Lacking stable emotional relationships due to busy schedules, work commitments, or a lack of social skills can lead to feelings of loneliness and a desire for attention. However, by helping and protecting female players, they experience a sense of being needed and valued, achieving emotional fulfillment.

At the same time, the game’s clear interaction rules and controllable environment offer certainty and a sense of security compared to the complexity and uncertainty of real life, reducing fears about unpredictable social interactions. However, prolonged reliance on virtual gratification within games may negatively impact their ability to form and maintain healthy emotional relationships in reality.

Reality pressure

Games offer a virtual world where players can temporarily escape the pressures, challenges, or unpleasant emotions of reality. This is particularly true for young people facing academic stress, family issues, or relationship difficulties, for whom games may be a way to seek comfort and relaxation.

Games are often designed to provide players with a sense of accomplishment and recognition for completing tasks, leveling up, or defeating opponents. Young people may become addicted to games because they offer a feeling of being appreciated and acknowledged, which they may lack in their real lives.

After getting older, they don’t like playing anymore

When young, individuals face fewer social responsibilities and pressures, allowing more time and energy for gaming. As they enter the workforce and start families, increased responsibilities make time and energy more valuable, potentially leading to gaming being seen as a time sink rather than a preferred leisure activity.

As people age, their cognitive abilities and interests evolve. What might appeal to someone in their youth—fast-paced, visually impressive games—may later give way to a preference for strategic, story-driven, or more complex experiences. If the market fails to meet these changing needs, interest will naturally decline.
